intro: Draba wahlenbergii var. longistyla, commonly known as the long-styled whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to the Arctic and alpine regions of Europe and North America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, clustered flowers and narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold, high-altitude environments. Its flowers are usually white or pale yellow, and it produces small, round pods that contain several seeds. This variant is distinguished by its elongated stigmas, which give it its specific epithet "longistyla."
